Joe, I'm still getting the feeling we don't really disagree on 
anything.  =
The last thing you said is that pattern recognition "is 
beneficial indepen=
dent of whether a traditional developmental 
encoding is used."  I think th=
at's pretty consistent with my 
argument that a traditional developmental e=
ncoding does not 
necessarily hold any advantages just by virtue of its unf=
olding over 
time or local interaction.  

You also point out that CPPNs in=
 effect do something similar in a 
more explicit way.  And I agree that it'=
s an interesting question 
whether implicit vs. explicit matters for this k=
ind of "targeting" 
ability.  My guess is that explicit is the same or bett=
er because 
making such an operation implicit makes it somewhat indirect, w=
hich 
means the route to a particular goal state may become more 
convolute=
d due to an inability to simply say directly what it should 
be.  

These a=
re obviously subtle issues that merit more research, since I 
am speaking o=
nly from intuition.  It's a really interesting topic.  
We can talk about t=
his more in Hawaii in a couple days :)

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, J=
oseph Reisinger <joeraii@...> wrote:
>
> > Joe, I may not be fully understa=
nding your point, so I wanted to 
ask
> > for clarification.
> > My point w=
as only that CPPNs can abstract away
> > the temporal unfolding and local i=
nteraction that are usually
> > associated with development.  You are sayin=
g something that does 
not
> > seem in opposition to this point, but I may =
be 
misunderstanding.  It
> > seems you are saying that "pattern recognitio=
n" gives a powerful
> > capability to traditional developmental systems in =
terms of being
> > able to target mutations to specific areas.  I would not=
 disagree
> > with that point.
> 
> Right, but such pattern matching is ind=
ependent of the 
developmental  
> process, its a representational feature =
that could be added in to 
any  
> indirect encoding. Its just a different =
way of specifying locality 
in  
> a slightly more "unstructured" way than =
is done with CPPNs. In 
fact  
> it could certainly be used with CPPNs, in =
the same way we use it 
for  
> neural networks.
> 
> I want to be clear th=
at I believe the idea of "pattern 
recognition"  
> in development is compl=
etely independent of local interactions  
> determining "where am i?" Furth=
ermore, I believe this idea plays 
a  
> role in determining evolvability.
=
> 
> >
> > However, what I would say, which may simply be consistent with 
=
what
> > you are saying, is that CPPNs abstract away the need for there 
to=
 be
> > such pattern recognition in order to get either global or local
> >=
 targeted mutations.  I still submit that the targeted mutations 
to
> > wh=
ich you are referring ultimately hinge on "where am I?"  
Because
> > how d=
id the liver cell ultimately figure out it was a liver cell?
> > It's becau=
se of its neighbors, and so forth.  It's all context-
> > dependent.
> 
> B=
ut it doesn't have to be determined from the neighbors. A cell 
could  
> j=
ust have a context determined by overlapping regulatory regions 
on a  
> f=
ixed substrate (like how CPPNS and implicit NEAT work). These  
> overlappi=
ng regulatory regions are what I'm trying to get at here: 
A  
> regulatory=
 region in a gene does exactly the "pattern 
recognition"  
> that we are d=
iscussing. For instance, a cell at some fixed 
location  
> could respond t=
o some regulatory signals A, B, and C. These 
signals  
> exactly determine=
 the cell's context within development, and 
other  
> cells with the exact=
 same signals would be treated the same, even  
> though they may be locate=
d in spatially diverse areas.
> 
> >
> > On the other hand, in the CPPN, th=
e liver is a local coordinate
> > frame (i.e. some internal node) that is b=
uilt upon (i.e. a 
function
> > of) other coordinate frames.  So in effect =
the same thing is 
going
> > on, just in a different way.  But ultimately i=
t "knows" it is a
> > liver cell in either case.  In the CPPN this knowledg=
e is simply
> > encapsulated as the node in the CPPN itself where the coord=
inate
> > frame is represented.  A mutation thereabout will effect only 
th=
ose
> > cells within that coordinate frame.  So you get targeted 
mutations=

> > just as well without "pattern recognition."
> 
> Right, this is a good=
 example. The hierarchical nesting of 
coordinate  
> frames in CPPNs and t=
he idea of doing pattern recognition for  
> matching regulatory signals ac=
complish the same goal, although 
they  
> are wildly different approaches.=
 One could almost say that a CPPN  
> builds definitions of locality "expli=
citly" while the regulatory  
> approach builds it "implicitly." Which of t=
hese representations 
is  
> better for what problems is an interesting ope=
n problem in  
> representation design.
> 
> >
> > I think what I'm saying =
is consistent with the results that you 
cite
> > from your paper since I f=
ully believe that IF you are using a
> > traditional developmental encoding=
, "pattern recognition" indeed
> > carries the benefits you cite.  So I exp=
ect you could 
demonstrate it
> > experimentally.
> 
> Again to be clear wh=
ere I disagree with you, "pattern 
recognition"  
> can be used and is bene=
ficial independent of whether a 
traditional  
> developmental encoding is =
used.
> 
> >
> > I think this is a great discussion to have.
> >
> > ken
> =
>
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Joseph Reisinger <joeraii@> wrote:
> >>
=
> >> Hi Ken,
> >>
> >> I have one (small) point of clarification to add to =
your
> > exposition
> >> here:
> >>
> >>> "genes essentially 'pattern recog=
nize' certain areas in the
> >>> organism"
> >>>
> >>> That is absolutely c=
orrect for biological organisms, and for
> >>> iterated developmental syste=
ms in general.  However, the deep
> >>> question is *why* should they need =
to "pattern recognize" 
certain
> >>> areas?
> >>>
> >>> And the answer is =
because they need to know where they are.  In
> >>> effect, in the physical=
 universe, there is no intrinsic
> > coordinate
> >>> system that cells can=
 query to ask their location.  Thus, they
> > must
> >>> develop elaborate =
and ad hoc ways of communicating to each
> > other, as
> >>> a group, where=
 everyone is.  I send my neighbor signals, my
> > neighbor
> >>> sends me s=
ignals back, and we negotiate our roles.
> >>>
> >>> My undoubtedly controv=
ersial contention is that the
> > question "where
> >>> am I?" is the ONLY =
reason that such negotation is necessary.  
If
> > you
> >>> didn't have to=
 ask that question, then you would not need to
> > talk to
> >>> your neigh=
bors in order to determine your role.  Rather, you
> > could
> >>> just com=
pute your role as a function of your known
> >>> coordinate/position in the=
 world.
> >>
> >> Your answer to "why we need to pattern recognize" is a li=
ttle
> >> incomplete. Basically you've only answered this from the cell's
>=
 >> perspective. Lets consider "pattern recognize" from the
> > perspective=

> >> of the developmental program instead of the cell. Then the main
> >> =
question is "how do I select a bunch of cells that match some
> >> property=
?" That is, I want to select some contiguous region,
> > e.g.,
> >> "toe ce=
lls" or "heart cells" or maybe I want to select something
> > more
> >> dev=
elopmentally useful, e.g. "epithelial cells" or "cells in 
some
> >> stripe=
 pattern along the HOX axis."
> >>
> >> Why is this useful? Because then we=
 can make mutations that
> > affect
> >> these areas and no others, i.e. mu=
tation selectivity that is
> > defined
> >> for some (hopefully) useful phe=
notypic axes of variation. A lot
> > of
> >> useful things fall out natural=
ly from this idea, like modularity
> > or
> >> evolvability (this is where =
I cite my GECCO 2007 paper, which is
> > not
> >> yet on the web). In CPPN =
terms it would be like being able to
> > select,
> >> say, all the black st=
ripes in a sine grating, but not the white
> > ones.
> >> If I'm not mistak=
en, CPPNs support this idea of regional
> > selection
> >> very nicely, so =
I'm not sure why you don't mention it here.
> >>
> >> Anyway, I totally agr=
ee that doing away with the "negotiation"
> > step
> >> required for develo=
pmental systems using purely local 
interactions
> > is
> >> a useful optim=
ization, but I wouldn't be so quick to say that
> > being
> >> able to "pat=
tern recognize" certain areas serves the sole 
purpose
> > of
> >> localiza=
tion with respect to only the global coordinate system.
> >>
> >> I'll go i=
nto this issue in more detail in my talk at GECCO, but 
I
> >> think its ve=
ry important, and our empirical results seem to back
> > it
> >> up quite s=
trongly.
> >>
> >> -- Joe
> >>
> >> http://www.cs.utexas.edu/~joeraii
